description.narrative: a. Strengthened capacity of the Department of Resettlement to manage resettlement schemes informed by the human security approach and to coordinate, implement, and integrate the programme efficiently in planning processes with different stakeholders. b. Improved access to primary health care and water and sanitation facilities, increasing diversified livelihood opportunities, and promoting sustainable management of natural resources and access to low-cost energy efficient technologies. c. Improved community cohesion and integration through community dialogue and campaigns, coordination of partners, set-up of infrastructure and systems to promoting and protect rights.

comment.narrative: 2014-2016 Strategic Framework for Local Integration of former refugees in Zambia 2016 Resettlement Policy 6th National Development Plan 2016 - 2021 UN-GRZ Sustainable Development Partnership Framework

Government at national and sub-national level undertake inclusive and participatory planning and governance processes that incorporate the targeted resettlement schemes Resettlement communities have access to context specific diversified livelihood opportunities Resettlement communities have capacity and structures to equitably and sustainably manage natural resources Resettlement communities are well-established and connected to neighbouring settlement areas Resettlement communities are tolerant, inclusive and integrated with the surrounding society, enabling people to live in peace and harmony to realise their aspirations

•Ongoing efforts to develop the resettlement schemes in 2019 and 2020 resulted in an increase in the number of households relocating to the resettlement schemes, which is a key indicator of the success of the approach. As of December 2020, a total of 1,338 households had relocated to the resettlement schemes (641 in Mayukwayukwa and 697 in Meheba), which is compared to 1,098 in 2019, 795 in 2018 and 660 in 2017. To support local level planning and governance in line with the decentralized focus of the government and the 7th National Development Plan and to promote the human security approach, Ward Development Committees were established and trained and several discussion and engagements at district levels centred on the inclusion of refugees, former refugees, and host communities in development planning at the district level. •There was improvement and ongoing efforts in provision of social services and infrastructure including initiation of road and bridge rehabilitation and capacity building for construction of low-cost houses. Efforts to advance economic opportunities and improve food security, were made through provision of agricultural inputs, tools and trainings for farmers, including vulnerable households, and development of other value chains (cashews, rice, honey). Addressing environmental and natural resource protection improved in 2019 through the establishment of community-based Natural Resource Management Committees through partners, with waste and natural resource management action plans developed. •Awareness raising activities on rights and responsibilities were undertaken. This included orientation and awareness raising sessions in the community on prevention of violence, abuse and exploitation, including designing a comprehensive action plan and coordination procedures on gender-based violence (GBV). Inclusion of women and youth in community groups and leadership roles has been key and local leadership structures are involved. The construction of a police post in Mayukwayukwa coupled with the establishment of neighbourhood watch and human rights committees strengthened security in the schemes and recreational equipment to create communal spaces to promote cohesion and interaction was constructed and delivered.

• Through the construction of 32.6 Kilometers of access roads in Meheba Resettlement Scheme, communities will be able to adequately access services such as education and health facilities and will also be able to transport produce to market. • Community members will be provided with specialized services from trained personnel as the construction of low cost housing units will be provided to trained staff. The community will also be capacity built to to undertake construction of low cost housing units. • Training of community groups in Forestry management and Financial Inclusion management will ensure that the communitys capacity to undertake income generation and manage their community resources is enhanced.
